items.message:
River levels are falling on the Bristol Avon, Tetbury Avon, Sherston Avon, Dauntsey Brook.  Areas most at risk include the road at Reybridge..
Further rain over the next few days is likely to cause river levels to rise again.

We are monitoring rainfall and river levels, checking rivers for blockages and clearing debris from weed screens in the area.
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.
Plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.

This message will be updated on Sunday evening, or sooner if the situation changes.

Flooding is expected in this area. This means properties are at risk of flooding.

Please take action to protect yourself and your property and monitor local weather and river conditions. Avoid contact with, walking or driving through flood water. Consider activating any property flood protection products you may have.

Environment Agency Flood Warning Officers set the river or tidal levels that have triggered this message. During industrial action this message has been automatically issued based on rising river or tidal levels.

items.description: River Thame, Horsenden Stream and Chalgrove Brook

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Thame, Horsenden Stream, Chalgrove Brook

items.message: Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels remain high but are beginning to fall on the River Thame as a result of recent heavy rain. Therefore, flooding of low lying land and roads is expected to continue, especially in the Thame, Stadhampton and Dorchester areas. Heavy rainfall is forecast overnight 12/11/23 and into tomorrow morning with low confidence over exact locations and timings. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated by tomorrow, 13/11/23, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Stour and Smestow Brook in the Black Country and South Staffordshire
items.message:
River levels are forecast to rise at the Swindon river gauge as a result of expected heavy rainfall. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is expected between 04:45 and 13:45 tomorrow, 13/11/2023.  
We expect river levels to rise until 10:00 tomorrow, 13/11/23.
We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are liaising with emergency services and actively checking river levels and the weather forecast.  
Please avoid using low lying footpaths and bridges near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
This message will be updated by 09:00 tomorrow, 13/11/23, or as the situation changes.

Flooding is affecting low-lying land and roads adjacent to the River Blythe between Cheswick Green and Blyth End.
We expect river levels to rise until 10:45 tomorrow, 13/11/23.
We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are liaising with emergency services and actively checking river levels and the weather forecast.  
Please avoid using low lying footpaths and bridges near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
This message will be updated by 09:00 tomorrow, 13/11/23, or as the situation changes.

Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels remain high but are beginning to fall on the River Cole as a result of recent heavy rain. Therefore, flooding of property and roads is possible this morning 12/11/23, especially in the Inglesham. Heavy rainfall is forecast overnight 12/11/23 and into tomorrow morning with low confidence over exact locations and timings. We expect river levels to continue to fall and then begin rising tomorrow morning 13/11/23. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated by tomorrow, 13/11/23, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Upper River Derwent, Stonethwaite Beck and Derwent Water

items.message:
River levels are forecast to rise at the Pillings Lock river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible from 05:30 tomorrow, 13/11/2023.  Areas most at risk are low-lying agricultural land and roads including Slash Lane at Sileby and the Mountsorrel to Sileby road.   

Further rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours.  We expect river levels to remain high until Wednesday 15/11/2023.

We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are patrolling watercourses in the area.  

Please plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded and avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses.  

This message will be updated by 09:00 on 13/11/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
River levels remain high following recent rainfall. Unsettled weather is forecast to continue with persistent rain over Sunday night on 12th November and Monday morning on 13th November, bringing a risk of flooding from the early hours of Monday morning. We expect flooding to affect Dartmeet, Ashburton, Buckfastleigh, Totnes, Brixham. Catchments are wet, so river levels will remain high and respond to further rainfall.  Flooding is possible on Monday morning.
Take care near the areas of concern and monitor your local weather conditions. 
We are constantly monitoring river levels. This message will be updated on Monday.

River levels are forecast to rise overnight at the Ashford river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible on Monday morning, 13/11/2023.  Areas most at risk are low-lying agricultural land and roads including Ashford and Bakewell areas.   
  
We are closely monitoring the situation.  
Please avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
This message will be updated by 09:00 tomorrow morning, 13/11/2023, or as the situation changes.

Monday morning's tide at 09:15 AM is higher than normal due to unsettled weather with westerly force 6 winds and large waves.
Areas most at risk include Christchurch Harbour and tidal stretches of the Lower Stour and Avon.
Flooding is possible at Christchurch Harbour and tidal stretches of the Lower Stour and Avon between 07:00 PM and 11:00 AM on 13/11/2023.
Weather conditions are expected to produce large onshore waves.
We are expecting higher than normal tides over the next 2 days and as a result we may issue further alerts/warnings.
Our incident response staff are closing flood gates and checking defences.
We will continue to monitor levels closely.
Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous.

We are expecting higher than normal tides over the next 2  days and as a result we may issue further alerts/warnings.

items.description: North Cornwall coast from Lands End to Chapel Porth
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
Flooding is possible over the high tide on Monday Morning. High water at St Ives is at 4.45am, times of high water will vary along the coast. 

Spring tides combined with force 8 south westerly winds and offshore wave heights of 3-4m are forecast to cause wave overtopping and sea spray in exposed coastal locations including St Ives Harbour, Portreath Harbour and the Causeway at Hayle. 

Expect tides to be up to 0.4m higher than predicted due to weather conditions. 

People are advised to stay away from risk areas and take care next to the coast. Keep up to date with weather and tide conditions on local radio. We will continue to monitor the situation and issue updates by midday on Monday or earlier if the situation changes. 

Detailed tidal information for those who use it; The forecast high tide level at Padstow is 3.8 mAOD, this is 0.4 metres above astronomical tide level.

Monday morning's tide at 10:30 on 13/11/2023 and 12:42 on 13/11/2023 is higher than normal, with strong Westerly Force 5 winds. The weather increases tide table values by 0.47 m. The total forecast tide is 4.18 metres Chart Datum (2.18 mAOD) at Beaulieu. For 30 minutes either side of high water, the tide will flood into the garden of the mill house on the downstream side of the Mill Pond. Minor road flooding at Palace Lane is also expected, making access to the village temporarily more difficult. High tide at 22:45 on 13/11/2023 will cause no impact. At 11:03 on 14/11/2023 the tide and flood impacts should be similar. We will issue further advice. We continue to monitor the forecast. For safety, please take care if walking or driving through Beaulieu. The incoming tide will flood the main road quickly. We will update this message by 14:00 on 13/11/2023.

items.message:
River levels remain high following recent rainfall. Unsettled weather is forecast to continue with heavy and persistent rain over Sunday night, bringing a further risk of flooding from the early hours of Monday morning. 

Catchments are wet, so river levels will remain high and respond to further rainfall. Flooding to low lying land and roads close to the Rivers Tamar, Neet and Strat is possible. 

Monitor your local weather conditions and avoid using low lying footpaths or entering areas prone to flooding. Do not walk or drive through flood water. We have staff in the area checking for and clearing blockages. We will be monitoring the situation and will issue updates by midday on Monday or earlier if the situation changes.

items.message: River levels remain high on the upper river Derwent. Levels have now peaked and continue to fall slowly. Flooding of low lying land is possible in this area. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please take action to protect yourself and your property, and monitor local weather and river conditions. Avoid contact with, walking or driving through flood water. We continue to monitor the situation and will update this message at 9pm on Sunday, 12/11/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: The tidal River Waveney from Ellingham to Breydon Water
items.message: This message has been issued because some flooding to riverside roads and footpaths is likely to continue throughout today, Sunday 12th November.  High water levels are likely to last for the next few days.  This is due to a natural tide locking effect of the Broads river system combined with the recent high rainfall.  We expect to see high water levels at Beccles Quay.  The weather forecast is for a few showers today, Sunday 12th November.  There is a weather front arriving in the early hours of Monday 13th November, which is forecast to bring widespread rain on Monday morning with some of this potentially being heavy.  Flood water is dangerous.  Don't put yourself or others at risk.  We are closely monitoring the situation.  We will update this message on Monday 13th November 2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: The tidal River Yare from Thorpe St Andrew to Breydon Water

 The weather forecast is for a few showers today, Sunday 12th November.  There is a weather front arriving in the early hours of Monday 13th November, which is forecast to bring widespread rain on Monday morning with some of this potentially being heavy.  Flood water is dangerous.  Don't put yourself or others at risk.  We are closely monitoring the situation.  We will update this message on Monday 13th November 2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: North Devon coast from Hartland Point to Lynmouth
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
Flooding is possible over the morning tide on Monday 13th November. Strong force 8 south westerly winds and offshore wave heights of over 3.5m are forecast to cause wave overtopping of sea defences and sea spray in exposed coastal locations.
    
The forecast peak water level at Ilfracombe is 4.86mAOD, 0.73m above published tide levels, due to surge. The time of high water at Ilfracombe on Monday morning is at 05:38 . Times of high tide will vary along the coast. Conditions may apply up to 2 hours either side of high water.  We will continue to monitor the tidal forecast and update the situation as required. 
 
Avoid beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 13/11/23, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Coast from Silloth to St Bees
items.message:
This Flood Alert has been issued due to the high tide forecast at 11:15 AM on 13/11/2023.
Tides are expected to be higher than usual due to the forecast weather conditions during coming tides.
Flooding is possible at low lying areas along the coast from Silloth to St Bees Head including Allonby, Maryport, Flimby, Workington, Parton and Whitehaven between 09:15 AM and 01:15 PM on 13/11/2023.
Storm Debi is forecast to bring south-westerly force 11 winds and produce large onshore waves.
The following high tide is also expected to be higher than normal and may result in us issuing a further alert.
We will continue to monitor levels closely and have closed flood gates in the area.
Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous.
Plan driving routes to avoid coastal roads, which may be flooded.
This message will be updated by 09:00 AM on 13/11/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.message:
Further rain, including heavy downpours, is forecast through Sunday and into the early hours of Monday 13 November,, therefore flooding remains possible over the next few days.

River levels remain high on the Washford River, Horner Water, River Aller, Hawkcombe Stream, Monksilver Stream, Doniford Stream and tributaries, with surrounding low-lying land being the areas most at risk.

Please consider weather conditions, local water levels and your flood plan if you have one. Avoid using low lying footpaths, roads and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.

Environment Agency officers are closely watching the situation. This message will be updated by 9am on 13/11/23.

items.description: River Erewash in Derbyshire and Nottinghamshire
items.message:
River levels are forecast to rise at the Pinxton river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall overnight.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible on Monday morning 13/11/2023.  Areas most at risk are low-lying agricultural land and roads around Pinxton, including the Pinxton Wharf access road, Langley Mill, Ilkeston, Stapleford, and the recreation area at Sandiacre.   
  
We are closely monitoring the situation.  
Please avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
This message will be updated by 09:00 tomorrow morning, 13/11/2023, or as the situation changes.

For water levels on the River Tone and Currymoor Drain at Currymoor pumping station please refer to our website: Check For Flooding (check-for-flooding.service.gov.uk).

Water will enter Currymoor reservoir via Hookbridge spillway whilst the River Tone level exceeds 7.45 m.

We are utilising our pumping stations, including additional temporary pumps, as water levels allow. The Parrett Relief Channel is being used to evacuate the water away from the Parrett-Tone confluence.

Further rain, is forecast through Sunday evening and into the early hours of Monday 13/11/23, therefore flooding remains possible over the next few days.

Please consider weather conditions, local water levels and your flood plan if you have one. Avoid using low lying footpaths, roads and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.

Environment Agency Flood Warning Officers continue to monitor the situation

River levels are forecast to rise at the Llanymynech river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is expected to begin between 7am and 10am tomorrow, 13/11/23.  We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the river from the Welsh border at Llawnt to Shrawardine near Shrewsbury. Other locations that may be affected include Llanymynech, Maesbrook and Melverley. Minor roads between Maesbrook, Melverley and Pentre start to flood. Predicted peaks:-  Llanymynech initial peak 2.8 to 3.2m expected this evening followed by another peak of between 4.0 to 4.5m Monday evening; Cae Howel 4.4m to 4.9m over night Monday.   
Further heavy rainfall is forecast over the next 48 hours.  
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are checking defences.  
Please avoid contact with flood water.  
This message will be updated by 10:00 on 13/11/23, or as the situation changes.

We continue to monitor the situation.  Our incident response staff are checking the condition of defences.

Therefore, flooding of low lying land and roads is expected to continue, especially in the Abingdon area. Heavy rainfall is forecast overnight 12/11/23 and into tomorrow morning with low confidence over exact locations and timings. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated by tomorrow, 13/11/23, or as the situation changes.

Water levels in the Eastern Yar remain high. In the last 24 hours, up to 7mm of rainfall has fallen, this caused the river to rise slightly, but levels at Alverstone are now stable. Water levels are continuing to fall at Sandown. A weak frontal system will cross the Isle of Wight Sunday, which will bring light rainfall. On Monday 13/11/2023, a weather system will cross the Isle of Wight. Between 00:00 and 04:00, an average of 5-7mm rainfall is forecast, and a further 4-8mm between 08:00 and 10:00. However, alternative scenarios suggest up to 35mm of rain could fall tomorrow. Flooding will continue to affect low lying land in the coming days. Ditches around Fort Holiday Park Sandown will struggle to drain while river levels are high. Water levels are likely to start rising at Alverstone during Monday morning, and at Sandown on Monday afternoon or evening. We are operating Bembridge sluice so that water is able to flow out to sea, between high tides. We continue to monitor the forecast. Avoid walking or driving through flood water. This message will be updated by 12:00 13/11/2023

items.description: Upper Avon River Swift and Clay Coton Brook
items.message:
River levels are forecast to rise at the Clay Coton and Lilbourne river gauges as a result of expected heavy rainfall. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is expected between 05:00 and 23:15 tomorrow, 13/11/23. We expect river levels to rise until 11:00 tomorrow, 13/11/23.
We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are liaising with emergency services and actively checking river levels and the weather forecast.  
Please avoid using low lying footpaths and bridges near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
This message will be updated by 09:00 tomorrow, 13/11/23, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Tributaries on the Upper River Thames above Cricklade

floodArea.riverOrSea: Flagham Brook, Swill Brook, Hankerton Brook, Hykemeres Stream, Derry Brook, River Key

items.message: Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels are high but steady on the Upper Thames tributaries as a result of recent heavy rain. Therefore, flooding of low lying land and roads is expected to continue, especially in the Oaksey and Swill Brook area. Heavy rainfall is forecast overnight 12/11/23 and into tomorrow morning with low confidence over exact locations and timings. We expect river levels to begin rising tomorrow morning 13/11/23. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated by tomorrow, 13/11/23, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Yeo, River Cam, River Wriggle, Barwick Stream, West Coker Stream

items.message:
Further rain, including heavy downpours, is forecast through Sunday and into the early hours of Monday 13/11/23, therefore flooding remains possible over the next few days.

Areas most at risk include the Sparkford to Weston Bampfylde road and Deep Ford Lane, Chetnole.

Please consider weather conditions, local water levels and your flood plan if you have one. Avoid using low lying footpaths, roads and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.

Environment Agency Flood Warning Officers continue to monitor the situation.

items.message:
Flooding is possible in this area.

Monitor local water levels and weather conditions. Avoid using low lying footpaths or entering areas prone to flooding. Start acting on your flood plan if you have one.

Environment Agency Flood Warning Officers set the river or tidal levels that have triggered this message. During industrial action this message has been automatically issued based on rising river or tidal levels.

Flood alert area: Chertsey Bourne including Virginia Water, Thorpe Green and Chertsey and the Moat at Thorpe.

items.description: Minor Watercourses from Heighington to Dunston
items.message: Rainfall over the last few weeks in Heighington to Dunston area, combined with high ground water levels, means that river levels have remained high. Further rainfall is expected over the next few days, which could mean river levels rise again. This will lead to flooding of low-lying land and roads close to the river. Our forecasts indicate that flooding inside properties is not likely, and therefore flood warnings are not expected to be issued. We are constantly monitoring river levels, and have staff in the field checking for blockages and clearing weed screens. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses, and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated as the situation changes.

River levels are forecast to rise at the Agnes Meadow Bridge river gauge as a result of expected heavy rainfall. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is expected between 05:00 and 17:45 tomorrow, 13/11/23.  Flooding is affecting low-lying land and roads adjacent to the River Dove between Izaak Walton and Rocester and the Henmore Brook between Carsington Dam and Mayfield.   
We expect river levels to rise until 09:30 tomorrow, 13/11/23.
We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are liaising with emergency services and actively checking river levels and the weather forecast.  
Please avoid using low lying footpaths and bridges near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
This message will be updated by 09:00 tomorrow, 13/11/23, or as the situation changes.

River levels remain high but are beginning to fall at the Lugwardine river gauge.  Consequently, the risk of flooding remains.  We expect flooding to affect Low lying land and roads adjacent to the River Lugg south of Leominster from Stoke Prior to Mordiford. Other locations that may be affected include Bodenham, Lugwardine and Hampton Bishop.   
River levels are falling, but still pose a flood risk.
We are closely monitoring the situation.
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses.  
This message will be updated by 10:00 on 13/11/23, or as the situation changes.

River levels are due to rise at the Slad Steanbridge Lane river gauge as a result of forecast heavy rainfall overnight tonight  Sunday 12th November through to the early hours of Monday morning. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible from this evening 12/11/23. We are closely monitoring the situation.  Please avoid contact with flood water.  
This message will be updated by 10am on 13/11/23 or as the situation changes.

items.description: The River Waveney from Diss and the River Dove to Ellingham, including Bungay
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to low lying land, roads and riverside areas is likely to continue today, Sunday 12th November.  River levels remain higher than normal and will be responsive to any further rainfall.  Areas most at risk are low lying roads and riverside areas around Diss, Eye, Harleston and Bungay.  The forecast is for a few showers today, Sunday 12th November.  There is a weather front arriving in the early hours of Monday 13th November, which is forecast to bring widespread rain on Monday morning with some of this potentially being heavy.  Flood water is dangerous.  Don't put yourself or others at risk.  We are closely monitoring the situation.  We will update this message on Monday 13th November 2023 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Hundred Foot Washes in Cambridgeshire and Norfolk

floodArea.riverOrSea: Old Bedford River, New Bedford River, Hundred Foot Drain, River Delph

items.message:
This information is correct as of 3:30pm on Sunday 12th November 2023.

The causeway at Welney has less than 1 centimetre of water on the road. However, we expect the water level to begin rising again within the next few hours. We also have further rain forecast overnight. There are currently no issues on the Sutton Gault causeway or the Earith causeway. Due to the uneven surface of the roads, water may be deeper in places.

We will update this message by 8am tomorrow morning, Monday 13th November 2023.

items.description: River Cherwell from Lower Heyford down to and including Oxford

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Cherwell, Woodeaton Brook, Bayswater Brook, Marston Brook, Peasmoor Brook

items.message:
This Flood Alert has been removed. River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold. There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain. Heavy rainfall is forecast overnight 12/11/23 and into tomorrow morning with low confidence over exact locations and timings. We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.
Please refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels.

items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Coly, River Yarty, Umborne Brook

items.message:
River levels remain high following recent rainfall. Unsettled weather is forecast to continue with persistent rain over Sunday night on 12th November and Monday morning on 13th November, bringing a risk of flooding from the early hours of Monday morning. We expect flooding to affect  Seaton, Colyton, Axminster and Axmouth. Catchments are wet, so river levels will remain high and respond to further rainfall.  Flooding is possible on Monday morning.
Take care near the areas of concern and monitor your local weather conditions. 
We are constantly monitoring river levels. This message will be updated on Monday.

The Aldingbourne Rife is high but slowly falling. Flooding is thought to still be affecting the Tesco car park on Shripney Road, land and caravans at Riverside Caravan Centre and Rowan Park Caravan Park, and areas of Durban Road. Water will still affect fields near Shripney Lane and the A259. Only a small amount of rain (5-10mm) is forecast Sunday, which should only cause river levels to rise by a few centimetres, if at all. However, a further 10-15mm of rain is forecast for Monday, which could cause river levels to rise again, possibly by 10cm in Bersted. River levels in Barnham could also rise on both Sunday and Monday, but not currently thought high enough to affect property flooding in Barnham. The Aldingbourne Rife might not return to normal until the end of November. Some roads will be affected by flood water, please plan to avoid driving through routes vulnerable to flooding, including Shripney Lane. We are running our pumps at Felpham and keeping grilles clear to help reduce the risk of flooding. We will update this message by 11:00 13/11/2023.

items.description: River Yeo and River Parrett Moors around Muchelney and Thorney
items.message:
For water levels on the River Yeo and the Drain at Huish Episcopi pumping station please refer to our website: Check For Flooding (check-for-flooding.service.gov.uk).

Flooding will affect the road from Langport to Muchelney if this level exceeds 7.3 m, the road from Muchelney to Long load if this level exceeds 7.86 and the road from Muchelney to Thorney if this level exceeds 7.93 m.

We are utilising our pumping stations, as water levels allow. The Parrett Relief Channel is also being used to evacuate the water.

Further rain is forecast late on Sunday evening and Monday morning 13/11/23,  therefore flooding remains possible over the next few days.

Please consider weather conditions, local water levels and your flood plan if you have one. Avoid using low lying footpaths, roads and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.

Environment Agency Flood Warning Officers continue to monitor the situation.

The Combe Haven in Bulverhythe is high, but slowly falling. At Crowhurst, the Powdermill Stream is nearer to normal. Flooding will continue to affect Bexhill Road Recreation Ground in Bulverhythe. Minor flooding could continue to affect fields and rural roads. A small amount of rain (5-10mm) is forecast Sunday. River levels along the Combe Haven could rise by a small amount Sunday, possibly generating minor flood impacts affecting fields, gardens and roads. More rain is forecast Monday. A further 10-15mm of rain is possible, which could again cause minor flood impacts, with flood water a little closer to properties in both Crowhurst and Bulverhythe. With more rain forecast for Thursday, the river might not return nearer to normal level until next weekend. The river will be sensitive to any additional rainfall over the rest of winter. Flood protection products are recommended to be kept installed in Crowhurst, if you have them. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 11:00 13/11/2023.

The Aldingbourne Rife is high but slowly falling. Flooding is thought to still be affecting the Tesco car park on Shripney Road, land and caravans at Riverside Caravan Centre and Rowan Park Caravan Park, and areas of Durban Road. Water will still affect fields near Shripney Lane and the A259. Only a small amount of rain (5-10mm) is forecast Sunday, which should only cause river levels to rise by a few centimetres, if at all. However a further 10-15mm of rain is forecast for Monday, which could cause river levels to rise again, possibly by 10cm. With the rest of November forecast to remain unsettled, the Aldingbourne Rife might not return to normal until the end of November. Some roads will be affected by flood water, please plan to avoid driving through routes vulnerable to flooding, including Shripney Lane. We are running our pumps at Felpham and keeping grilles clear to help reduce the risk of flooding. We will update this message by 11:00 13/11/2023.

items.description: Rivers Yeo and Parrett, downstream of Yeovil to Steart

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Parrett, River Yeo, Cary, Sowy, Kings Sedgemoor Drain

items.message:
Further rain, including heavy downpours, is forecast through on Sunday and into the early hours of Monday 13/11/23, therefore flooding remains possible over the next few days.

Areas most at risk include the Ilchester to Yeovilton road at the end of the runway, the Mudford to Limington road, the road and properties at the south end of Westover Trading Estate.

We are utilising our pumping stations, including additional temporary pumps, as water levels allow. The Parrett Relief Channel is being used to evacuate the water away from the Parrett-Tone confluence.

Please consider weather conditions, local water levels and your flood plan if you have one. Avoid using low lying footpaths, roads and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.

Environment Agency Flood Warning Officers continue to monitor the situation

items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Avon, River Erme, River Harbourne

items.message:
River levels on the River Avon, River Erme and River Harbourne remain high following recent rainfall. Unsettled weather is forecast to continue with persistent rain over Sunday night on 12th November and Monday morning on 13th November, bringing a risk of flooding from the early hours of Monday morning. Catchments are wet, so river levels will remain high and respond to further rainfall.  Flooding is possible on Monday morning.
Take care near the areas of concern and monitor your local weather conditions. 
We are constantly monitoring river levels. This message will be updated on Monday.

As a result of high spring tides and strong winds, tides will be at their highest tomorrow morning at 05:30 AM on 13/11/2023.

Areas most at risk include properties situated behind East Beach, including Pier Terrace,  Waterside, The Bay House, The Old Watch House, Bridport Arms Hotel, Seagulls, Swains Row, The Old Timber Yard, Station Road, Station Way and George Street from 05:30 AM to 08:00 AM on 13/11/2023.
Weather conditions are expected to produce large onshore waves.
The forecast is for south-westerly force 7 winds tomorrow morning.
After this tide‚ the weather is more settled and no further impacts are expected.
We are erecting temporary flood barriers behind East Beach
We will continue to monitor levels closely.
Please stay away from beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as the expected large waves and sea spray will be dangerous.

items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
River levels remain high following recent rainfall. Unsettled weather is forecast to continue with heavy and persistent rain over Sunday night, bringing a further risk of flooding from the early hours of Monday morning. 

Catchments are wet, so river levels will remain high and respond to further rainfall. Flooding to low lying land and roads close to the River Lynher is possible. 

Monitor your local weather conditions and avoid using low lying footpaths or entering areas prone to flooding. Do not walk or drive through flood water. We have staff in the area checking for and clearing blockages. We will be monitoring the situation and will issue updates by midday on Monday or earlier if the situation changes.

items.description: Outlying villages on the Bure, Ant and Thurne
items.message: This message has been issued because of the ongoing impact and continued risk of flooding to homes and businesses, which will continue throughout today, Sunday 12th November.  High water levels are likely to last for the next few days.  This is due to a natural tide locking effect of the Broads river system combined with the recent high rainfall.  Areas most at risk are Ridlington, Briggate, Honing, East Rushton, Dilham, Sutton, Catfield Common, Hickling, Potter Heigham, Ludham, Bastwick, Martham, Damgate and Billockby, and the A149 and A1062 roads.  The weather forecast is for a few showers today, Sunday 12th November.  There is a weather front arriving in the early hours of Monday 13th November, which is forecast to bring widespread rain on Monday morning with some of this potentially being heavy.  Flood water is dangerous.  Don't put yourself or others at risk. We are closely monitoring the situation.  We will update this message on Monday 13th November 2023, or as the situation changes.

items.message:

Catchments are wet, so river levels will remain high and respond to further rainfall.  Flooding is possible on Monday morning.
Take care near the areas of concern and monitor your local weather conditions. 
We are constantly monitoring river levels. This message will be updated on Monday.

Flooding is possible in this area.

Monitor local water levels and weather conditions. Avoid using low lying footpaths or entering areas prone to flooding. Start acting on your flood plan if you have one.

Environment Agency Flood Warning Officers set the river or tidal levels that have triggered this message. During industrial action this message has been automatically issued based on rising river or tidal levels.

For water levels on the River Tone and Currymoor Drain at Currymoor pumping station please refer to our website: Check For Flooding (check-for-flooding.service.gov.uk).

Water will enter Currymoor reservoir via Hookbridge spillway whilst the River Tone level exceeds 7.45 m.

We are utilising our pumping stations, including additional temporary pumps, as water levels allow. The Parrett Relief Channel is being used to evacuate the water away from the Parrett-Tone confluence.

Further rain, is forecast through Sunday evening and into the early hours of Monday 13/11/23, therefore flooding remains possible over the next few days.

Please consider weather conditions, local water levels and your flood plan if you have one. Avoid using low lying footpaths, roads and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.

Environment Agency Flood Warning Officers continue to monitor the situation

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the West of Dorset
items.message: Groundwater levels have responded to the intense rainfall over the last few weeks, with the borehole at Kingston Russell rising to 115 metres overnight. The more westerly communities on the Chalk in Dorset, including those along the South Winterbourne Valley, Beaminster and Hooke will start to experience issues with septic tanks and roads may become flooded. Levels are expected to continue rising until at least the end of next week. You can monitor groundwater levels at the Kingston Russell borehole on the Check-for-Flooding.gov.uk website. Further heavy rainfall is expected in the middle of next week. Please avoid driving through flood water as the bow wave can flood nearby properties and can seriously damage your engine. If there is no alternative please drive very slowly to minimise damage. If you have property flood resilience measures such as pumps, air brick covers or flood barriers, you should consider putting them in place now. This message will be updated on Monday.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Upper Og Valley
items.message:
Groundwater levels have responded to recent rainfall and have risen at our observation borehole in Draycot Foliat in the Og Valley area. Groundwater levels are above normal for this time of year and remain at a level where communities may be affected by flooding from groundwater over the coming days. Groundwater levels in the area are currently stable but remain responsive to rainfall. No rainfall is forecast today 11/11/23, but heavy rainfall is expected overnight on Sunday into Monday, with the weather becoming more settled later in the week.
Groundwater level will continue to remain high and may still impact low lying gardens and cellars. Due to the nature of groundwater behaviour, this situation could continue for several weeks or longer.
We are continuing to monitor groundwater levels and will update this message by 18/11/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Cranborne Chase area
items.message:
Groundwater levels have risen above 99 metres at the Woodyates borehole, Levels are forecast to rise quite steeply for the next 48 hours at least. Flooding of minor roads is possible at this level. Some septic tanks are likely to fail with a continued rise in level. Areas most likely to be affected are the Vale of Allen, including Sixpenny Handley and the Chalke Valley. 
Householders with property level protection measures such as pumps, flood barriers and air brick covers should put them in place now.
Motorists should avoid driving through flood water as the bow wave can damage homes and car engines.
This message will be updated tomorrow, Monday

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the South Wiltshire Downs - The Dene
items.message:
The level at the nearby Terraces, Fonthill borehole has risen to 116 metres above sea level.  Flooding to properties from groundwater in the Dene Valley is now expected. The stream will remain high for several days. Ensure that pumps are operational and that other precautions such as airbrick covers and flood boards are in place. Avoid driving through flood water as the bow wave will cause properties to flood. 
Further rainfall is expected on Wednesday and at the beginning of next week which will keep levels high. A high pressure system may bring a brief respite from about the 15th; this may provide an opportunity to replenish any property level resilience measures.
This message will be updated on Tuesday.

items.description: Groundwater flooding for the South Winterbourne Valley
items.message:
The level at the nearby Kingston Russell borehole has risen to 116 metres above sea level.  Flooding to properties from groundwater in the South Winterbourne Valley is now expected. The Winterbourne will remain high for several days. Ensure that pumps are operational and that other precautions such as airbrick covers and flood boards are in place. Avoid driving through flood water as the bow wave will cause properties to flood. 
Further rainfall is expected on Wednesday and at the beginning of next week which will keep levels high. A high pressure system may bring a brief respite from about the 15th; this may provide an opportunity to replenish any property level resilience measures.
This message will be updated on Tuesday.

Flooding is possible in this area.

Monitor local water levels and weather conditions. Avoid using low lying footpaths or entering areas prone to flooding. Start acting on your flood plan if you have one.

Environment Agency Flood Warning Officers set the river or tidal levels that have triggered this message. During industrial action this message has been automatically issued based on rising river or tidal levels.
